what: Hypothesis Tests Using Biased and Unbiased Urn Models Inspired by Muriel Bristol and Ronald Fisher
title: Hypothesis Tests Using Biased and Unbiased Urn Models Inspired by Muriel Bristol and Ronald Fisher
text: set functions compute pp-values perform sensitivity analysis, adapting Fisher’s pp-value test case studies process tracing following López Bowers (2025). uses unbiased biased urn models draw null distributions absence randomization.

title: Hypothesis Tests Using Biased and Unbiased Urn Models Inspired by Muriel Bristol and Ronald Fisher
text: Since package still development, yet submitted CRAN. can install directly Github using following commands:

title: Hypothesis Tests Using Biased and Unbiased Urn Models Inspired by Muriel Bristol and Ronald Fisher
text: name package Dr. Murial Bristol, better known “tea lady” Fisher’s pp-value demonstration. Fewer people aware “lady” fellow researcher Rothamsted Research institute. Beyond brilliant scientist , Dr. Bristol indeed taste whether tea milk poured first cup, evidence suggests.

what: Calculate the difference between the p-value and a p-value threshold for the multiple types of information model — find_odds_multi

title: Calculate the difference between the p-value and a p-value threshold for the multiple types of information model — find_odds_multi
Calculate the difference between the p-value and a p-value threshold for the multiple types of information model — find_odds_multi
text: obs_support vector integers representing number observations made favor working hypothesis (anti-rival). element corresponds evidence specific rival. rival_obs Optional. vector integers representing number observations actually made support rival. Must length obs_support. NULL, assumes zero pro-rival observations. weights used yet. p_threshold number 0 1 indicating critical value test.

what: Calculate the difference between the p-value and a p-value threshold for the two types of observation model — find_odds_two_types
title: Calculate the difference between the p-value and a p-value threshold for the two types of observation model — find_odds_two_types
text: helper function sens_obs_two_types() see find_p_two_types() details.

title: Calculate the difference between the p-value and a p-value threshold for the two types of observation model — find_odds_two_types
code: find_odds_two_types(   omega,   obs_support,   total_obs,   rival_obs,   weights,   p_threshold )

title: Calculate the difference between the p-value and a p-value threshold for the two types of observation model — find_odds_two_types
text: obs_support integer representing number observations favor working hypothesis. Must less equal total_obs. total_obs integer representing total number observations made. can greater equal obs_support. rival_obs Optional. integer representing number observations urn support working theory. weights Double vector. Default equal weight observation weights=NULL rep(1,obs_support). indicate one observation twice weight one might use rep(c(2,1),c(1,obs_support-1)) p_threshold number 0 1 indicating critical value test.

title: Multi-rival testing: Max-P approach — find_p_multi_max_p
text: test composite null hypothesis least one rival theory consistent data working theory: Rival Theory 1 true Rival Theory 2 true ... Rival k true.

title: Multi-rival testing: Max-P approach — find_p_multi_max_p
code: find_p_multi_max_p(   obs_support,   total_obs,   rival_obs = NULL,   odds = 1,   weights = NULL )

title: Multi-rival testing: Max-P approach — find_p_multi_max_p
text: obs_support vector integers representing number observations favor working hypothesis. element must less equal corresponding element total_obs. total_obs vector integers representing total number observations made. elements can can greater equal obs_support. rival_obs Optional. integer representing number observations urn support working theory. odds odds observing rival versus working-theory observation. can interpreted "bias" observation. "relative ease" observation. weights Double vector. Default equal weight observation weights=NULL rep(1,obs_support). indicate one observation twice weight one might use rep(c(2,1),c(1,obs_support-1)) interpretation Logical. TRUE function returns text helping interpret result, FALSE (default option) returns p-value

title: Multi-rival testing: Max-P approach — find_p_multi_max_p
text: Either p-value (numeric, scalar) list containing p-value text containing interpretation

title: Multi-rival testing: Max-P approach — find_p_multi_max_p
text: reject composite hypothesis can reject individual hypotheses. two main approaches problem: (1) individual tests use maximum p-value (TODO cite Berger intersection-union test controlled FWER) (2) represent test single test using multivariate distribution. function implements first option calling find_p_two_types() element vectors provided . approach tends conservative.

title: Multi-rival testing: Max-P approach — find_p_multi_max_p
code: # Example 1: # One kind of working theory supporting information that argues against multiple rivals where # each rival has the same amount of information. # Notice that we will get the same answer as if we used `find_p_two_types()` directly. # But we present this here to illustrate. # 4 rivals, 10 observations of one kind of working theory supporting # observation, 10 total observations made find_p_multi_max_p(obs_support = rep(10, 4), total_obs = rep(10, 4)) #> [1] 2.835142e-06 find_p_two_types(obs_support = 10, total_obs = 10) #> [1] 2.835142e-06 # Example 2: # 4 kinds of working theory supporting observations, each of which is # inconsistent with a single rival, only working theory supporting observations # made. Notice the max p: find_p_multi_max_p(obs_support = c(4, 3, 2, 1), total_obs = c(4, 3, 2, 1)) #> [1] 0.3333333 find_p_two_types(obs_support = 4, total_obs = 4) #> [1] 0.007936508 find_p_two_types(obs_support = 3, total_obs = 3) #> [1] 0.02857143 find_p_two_types(obs_support = 2, total_obs = 2) #> [1] 0.1 find_p_two_types(obs_support = 1, total_obs = 1) #> [1] 0.3333333

title: Multi-rival testing: Multivariate Approach — find_p_multi_mv
text: test composite null hypothesis least one rival theory consistent data working theory: Rival Theory 1 true Rival Theory 2 true ... Rival k true. function tests INFORMATIVE observations — distinguish working theory rival theories. neutral/uninformative observations, exclude calling function. test : "Given n informative observations, likely observed pattern least one rival theory correct?"

title: Multi-rival testing: Multivariate Approach — find_p_multi_mv
code: find_p_multi_mv(   obs_support,   rival_obs = NULL,   weights = NULL,   odds = 1,   interpretation = FALSE,   check_evidence = TRUE,   messages = TRUE )

title: Multi-rival testing: Multivariate Approach — find_p_multi_mv
text: obs_support vector integers representing number observations made favor working hypothesis (anti-rival). element corresponds evidence specific rival. rival_obs Optional. vector integers representing number observations actually made support rival. Must length obs_support. NULL, assumes zero pro-rival observations. weights used yet. odds odds ratio sampling (default 1 central hypergeometric). Currently scalar indicating odds seeing working theory observations versus rivals. complicate future versions. interpretation Logical. TRUE, returns interpretation text p-value. check_evidence Logical. TRUE, checks obs_support identical across rivals suggests using find_p_multi_max_p() instead. pass message, set check_evidence=FALSE messages=FALSE messages Logical. TRUE, prints long message obs_support identical across rivals rival_obs=NULL. FALSE, print message.

title: Multi-rival testing: Multivariate Approach — find_p_multi_mv
text: Either numeric p-value (scalar) list p-value interpretation.

title: Multi-rival testing: Multivariate Approach — find_p_multi_mv
text: reject composite hypothesis can reject individual hypotheses. two main approaches problem: (1) individual tests use maximum p-value (see Berger intersection-union tests FWER control) (2) represent test single test using multivariate distribution. function implements second option using multivariate hypergeometric distribution. rejection region includes outcomes : Anti-rival evidence >= observed levels rivals (componentwise) Total pro-rival observations = observed total (zero none observed) possible allocations pro-rival observations across rival types interpretation: p > alpha: "reject union null hypothesis. observed evidence pattern sufficiently unlikely hypothesis least one rival theory correct. Therefore, strong enough evidence rule rival theories." p <= alpha: "reject union null hypothesis. observed evidence pattern occur chance 100*p% time least one rival theory actually correct. provides strong statistical evidence rival theories wrong working theory correct explanation." assume conservative urn model number pro-rival observations population obs_support + 1 rival (following Lopez Bowers 2026).

title: Multi-rival testing: Multivariate Approach — find_p_multi_mv
code: # Example 1: # One kind of working theory supporting information that argues against multiple rivals where # each rival has the same amount of information. # Notice that we will get the same answer as if we used `find_p_two_types()` directly. # But we present this here to illustrate. # 4 rivals, 10 observations of one kind of working theory supporting # observation, 10 total observations made find_p_multi_max_p(obs_support = rep(10, 4), total_obs = rep(10, 4)) #> [1] 2.835142e-06 find_p_multi_mv(obs_support = c(10, 10, 10, 10)) #> It looks like you have only one kind of evidence that is inconsistent with multiple rivals. You would over-state your evidence against the rivals if we used a multivariate null-model by repeating the same number of anti-Rival observations. We are reporting here the p-value from the find_p_multi_max_p command. If you actually do have multiple types of observations but happen to have the same numbers of them, then you should try this command again but set check_evidence=FALSE and messages=FALSE #> [1] 2.835142e-06 find_p_two_types(obs_support = 10, total_obs = 10) #> [1] 2.835142e-06 find_p_multi_max_p(obs_support = rep(10, 4), total_obs = rep(10, 4), odds = 2) #> [1] 7.707336e-05 find_p_multi_mv(obs_support = c(10, 10, 10, 10), odds = 2, messages = FALSE) #> [1] 7.707336e-05 # Example 2: No pro-rival observations made, different anti-rival evidence levels find_p_multi_mv(obs_support = c(4, 3, 2, 1)) #> [1] 5.098773e-07  # Example 3: With pro-rival observations find_p_multi_mv(obs_support = c(4, 3, 2, 1), rival_obs = c(1, 1, 0, 0)) #> [1] 3.36519e-05  # Example 4: With pro-rival observations and non-uniform odds find_p_multi_mv(obs_support = c(4, 3, 2, 1), rival_obs = c(1, 1, 0, 0), odds = 2) #> [1] 0.0007486185 find_p_multi_mv(obs_support = c(4, 3, 2, 1), rival_obs = c(1, 1, 0, 0), odds = .5) #> [1] 7.310727e-07

what: Find a p-value given a certain number of observations in favor of the working hypothesis among a total number of observations when there are two types of observations — find_p_two_types
title: Find a p-value given a certain number of observations in favor of the working hypothesis among a total number of observations when there are two types of observations — find_p_two_types
text: observation can either support working theory rival theory, function returns p-value summarizing minimum evidence rival theory provided working theory. function returns p=.01 take p<=.01.

title: Find a p-value given a certain number of observations in favor of the working hypothesis among a total number of observations when there are two types of observations — find_p_two_types
code: find_p_two_types(   obs_support,   total_obs,   rival_obs = NULL,   odds = 1,   weights = NULL,   interpretation = FALSE )

title: Find a p-value given a certain number of observations in favor of the working hypothesis among a total number of observations when there are two types of observations — find_p_two_types
text: obs_support integer representing number observations favor working hypothesis. Must less equal total_obs. total_obs integer representing total number observations made. can greater equal obs_support. rival_obs Optional. integer representing number observations urn support working theory. odds odds observing rival versus working-theory observation. can interpreted "bias" observation. "relative ease" observation. weights Double vector. Default equal weight observation weights=NULL rep(1,obs_support). indicate one observation twice weight one might use rep(c(2,1),c(1,obs_support-1)) interpretation Logical. TRUE function returns text helping interpret result, FALSE (default option) returns p-value

title: Find a p-value given a certain number of observations in favor of the working hypothesis among a total number of observations when there are two types of observations — find_p_two_types
text: Either p-value (numeric, scalar) list containing p-value text containing interpretation

title: Find a p-value given a certain number of observations in favor of the working hypothesis among a total number of observations when there are two types of observations — find_p_two_types
text: function accommodates urns working theory supporting observations systematically easier difficulty observe rival supporting observations via odds argument. also supports designs one observation total supporting working theory  particularly compelling ("smoking gun"). example, observation 1 worth 2 observations, urn can reflect increasing number observations supporting rival theory urn, accounting weight smoking gun observation using weights argument. function allows total number observations (total_obs) larger number supporting working theory (obs_support). design element.

title: Find a p-value given a certain number of observations in favor of the working hypothesis among a total number of observations when there are two types of observations — find_p_two_types
code: # Equal probability find_p_two_types(obs_support = 7, total_obs = 10) #> [1] 0.01864802 # Equal probability with interpretation printed find_p_two_types(obs_support = 7, total_obs = 10, interpretation = TRUE) #> The maximum probability of drawing 7 observations which support the working theory from an urn model supporting a rival theory, where the odds of observing working theory information is odds=1 and evidentiary weights are (1,1,1,1,1,1,1), is p <=0.0186. #> $thep #> [1] 0.01864802 #>  #> $interp #> [1] "The maximum probability of drawing 7 observations which support the working theory from an urn model supporting a rival theory, where the odds of observing working theory information is odds=1 and evidentiary weights are (1,1,1,1,1,1,1), is p <=0.0186." #>  # Equal probability where total obs is equal to the number of observations # # supporting the working theory. Notice that this is less conservative than # the above. find_p_two_types(obs_support = 7, total_obs = 7, interpretation = FALSE) #> [1] 0.0001554002 # Unequal probability, 2 kinds of evidence with interpretation printed find_p_two_types(obs_support = 7, total_obs = 10, interpretation = TRUE, odds = .5) #> The maximum probability of drawing 7 observations which support the working theory from an urn model supporting a rival theory, where the odds of observing working theory information is odds=0.5 and evidentiary weights are (1,1,1,1,1,1,1), is p <=0.003. #> $thep #> [1] 0.002989537 #>  #> $interp #> [1] "The maximum probability of drawing 7 observations which support the working theory from an urn model supporting a rival theory, where the odds of observing working theory information is odds=0.5 and evidentiary weights are (1,1,1,1,1,1,1), is p <=0.003." #>  find_p_two_types(obs_support = 7, total_obs = 10, interpretation = TRUE, odds = 2) #> The maximum probability of drawing 7 observations which support the working theory from an urn model supporting a rival theory, where the odds of observing working theory information is odds=2 and evidentiary weights are (1,1,1,1,1,1,1), is p <=0.0761. #> $thep #> [1] 0.07612251 #>  #> $interp #> [1] "The maximum probability of drawing 7 observations which support the working theory from an urn model supporting a rival theory, where the odds of observing working theory information is odds=2 and evidentiary weights are (1,1,1,1,1,1,1), is p <=0.0761." #>  # Equal probability, Unequal evidentiary weight, 2 kinds of evidence find_p_two_types(   obs_support = 7, total_obs = 10, weights = rep(1, 7),   interpretation = TRUE, odds = 1 ) #> The maximum probability of drawing 7 observations which support the working theory from an urn model supporting a rival theory, where the odds of observing working theory information is odds=1 and evidentiary weights are (1,1,1,1,1,1,1), is p <=0.0186. #> $thep #> [1] 0.01864802 #>  #> $interp #> [1] "The maximum probability of drawing 7 observations which support the working theory from an urn model supporting a rival theory, where the odds of observing working theory information is odds=1 and evidentiary weights are (1,1,1,1,1,1,1), is p <=0.0186." #>  find_p_two_types(   obs_support = 7, total_obs = 10,   weights = rep(c(2, 1), c(1, 7 - 1)), interpretation = TRUE, odds = 1 ) #> The maximum probability of drawing 7 observations which support the working theory from an urn model supporting a rival theory, where the odds of observing working theory information is odds=1 and evidentiary weights are (2,1,1,1,1,1,1), is p <=0.0105. #> $thep #> [1] 0.01048951 #>  #> $interp #> [1] "The maximum probability of drawing 7 observations which support the working theory from an urn model supporting a rival theory, where the odds of observing working theory information is odds=1 and evidentiary weights are (2,1,1,1,1,1,1), is p <=0.0105." #>

what: Sensitivity analysis for urn models with two types of information — sens_obs_multi
title: Sensitivity analysis for urn models with two types of information — sens_obs_multi
text: function allows researcher calculate odds drawing working theory supporting observation rival theory supporting observation required increase p-value certain value.

title: Sensitivity analysis for urn models with two types of information — sens_obs_multi
code: sens_obs_multi(   obs_support,   rival_obs = NULL,   weights = NULL,   p_threshold = 0.05 )

title: Sensitivity analysis for urn models with two types of information — sens_obs_multi
text: obs_support integer representing number observations favor working hypothesis. Must less equal total. rival_obs Optional. number observations urn support working theory. weights vector numeric weights representing differential evidentiary weight working theory supporting observations. p_threshold decimal (Double). p-value threshold. Default p=.05. total_obs integer representing total number observations

title: Sensitivity analysis for urn models with two types of information — sens_obs_multi
text: list two elements: w differential odds observing working theory supporting observation rival theory supporting observation. p p-value given found w.

title: Sensitivity analysis for urn models with two types of information — sens_obs_multi
code: # What is the odds that would bring our p=.02 to p \approx .05 find_p_multi_mv(obs_support = c(4, 3, 2, 1), odds = 1) #> [1] 5.098773e-07 find_p_multi_mv(obs_support = c(4, 3, 2, 1), odds = 2) #> [1] 2.036757e-05 sens_obs_multi(obs_support = c(4, 3, 2, 1), p_threshold = .05)$w #> [1] 22.53507 # Notice that this is correct: find_p_multi_mv(obs_support = c(4, 3, 2, 1), odds = 22.535) #> [1] 0.04999969 sens_obs_multi(obs_support = c(4, 3, 2, 1), rival_obs = c(1, 1, 0, 0), p_threshold = .05)$w #> [1] 8.168784 sens_obs_multi(obs_support = c(4, 4, 4, 4), p_threshold = .05) #> $w #> [1] 2.596286 #>  #> $p #> [1] 0.04999972 #>  find_p_multi_mv(obs_support = c(4, 4, 4, 4), odds = 2.6) #> It looks like you have only one kind of evidence that is inconsistent with multiple rivals. You would over-state your evidence against the rivals if we used a multivariate null-model by repeating the same number of anti-Rival observations. We are reporting here the p-value from the find_p_multi_max_p command. If you actually do have multiple types of observations but happen to have the same numbers of them, then you should try this command again but set check_evidence=FALSE and messages=FALSE #> [1] 0.05011704

title: Sensitivity analysis for urn models with two types of information — sens_obs_two_types
code: # What is the odds that would bring our p=.02 to p \approx .05 find_p_two_types(obs_support = 7, total_obs = 10, odds = 1) #> [1] 0.01864802 sens_obs_two_types(obs_support = 7, total_obs = 10, p_threshold = .05)$w #> [1] 1.58928 # Notice that this is correct: find_p_two_types(obs_support = 7, total_obs = 10, odds = 1.58928) #> [1] 0.04999995
